title: if Statements: Your First Decisions
concept:
Imagine you're programming a vending machine. A customer inserts money and selects an item that costs $1.50. Your program needs to decide:

"IF money >= 1.50, THEN dispense the item"

Without this ability to make decisions, your program could only do the exact same thing every time - like a music box that plays the same tune. With if statements, your programs become intelligent - they adapt, they respond, they decide.

Real-World Decision Points:

  • Automatic doors:
    IF sensor detects person → Open door
  • Thermostat:
    IF temperature < 68°F → Turn on heater
  • Email spam filter:
    IF message contains suspicious words → Move to spam folder
  • Video game:
    IF player presses spacebar → Make character jump

Every one of these decisions follows the same pattern:

IF (condition is True)
    THEN do these actions

In Python, we write this using the if statement!

The Power You're About to Gain:

In Lesson 1, you learned to ask Boolean questions ("Is age >= 18?"). In Lesson 2, you learned to combine them ("Is age >= 18 AND has_id?"). Now you'll learn to make your programs ACT on those answers:

if age >= 18:
    print("You can vote!")
    print("Register at your local polling station.")

This is the moment your programs transform from calculators into decision-makers!

code_example.code:
# if Statements: Making Your Programs Decide

# Example 1: Basic if statement
temperature = 105

if temperature > 100:
    print("Water is boiling!")
    print("Be careful!")

print("Temperature check complete.")
# Output:
# Water is boiling!
# Be careful!
# Temperature check complete.

print()

# Example 2: Condition is False - code doesn't run
temperature = 75

if temperature > 100:
    print("This won't print")  # Skipped! Condition is False

print("This always prints")  # Not indented, so always runs
# Output:
# This always prints

print()

# Example 3: User input validation
age = int(input("Enter your age: "))

if age >= 18:
    print("✓ You are eligible to vote!")
    print("✓ You can register at vote.gov")

if age >= 21:
    print("✓ You can purchase alcohol (in the US)")

if age >= 25:
    print("✓ You can rent a car without extra fees")

print("\nAge verification complete.")

print()

# Example 4: Multiple statements in the if block
score = 95

if score >= 90:
    print("Excellent work!")
    print("You earned an A grade.")
    grade = "A"
    bonus_points = 5
    print(f"Bonus points awarded: {bonus_points}")

print("Grading complete.")

print()

# Example 5: Combining with logical operators
password = "secret123"
username = "alice"

if username == "alice" and password == "secret123":
    print("✓ Login successful!")
    print("Welcome back, Alice!")
    is_logged_in = True

print()

# Example 6: Using Boolean variables
has_ticket = True
has_id = True

if has_ticket:
    print("✓ Ticket verified")

if has_ticket and has_id:
    print("✓ You may enter the venue")
    print("Enjoy the show!")

syntax_breakdown:
if Statement Anatomy:

if condition:
    statement1
    statement2
    statement3

Breaking It Down:

  1. The keyword: if (lowercase!)
    if  # Correct
IF  # ERROR! Python is case-sensitive
If  # ERROR! Must be lowercase
  2. The condition: Any Boolean expression
    if age >= 18:           # Comparison
if is_valid:            # Boolean variable
if score > 90 and passed_exam:  # Logical operators
if temperature > 32:    # Any expression that's True/False
  3. The colon (:): REQUIRED! Tells Python "here comes the code block"
    if age >= 18:  # Correct - has colon
if age >= 18   # ERROR! Missing colon
  4. Indentation: The code inside the if block MUST be indented
    # Correct - 4 spaces (or 1 tab)
if temperature > 100:
    print("Boiling")  # Indented
    print("Hot!")     # Indented

# ERROR - not indented
if temperature > 100:
print("Boiling")  # IndentationError!

How Python Reads an if Statement:

  1. Evaluate the condition (is it True or False?)
  2. If True → Execute all indented code
  3. If False → Skip all indented code
  4. Continue with non-indented code after the block

Visual Flow:

if temperature > 100:
    print("A")  ← Runs only if True
    print("B")  ← Runs only if True
print("C")      ← Always runs (not indented!)

# If temperature = 105 (True):
# Output: A, B, C

# If temperature = 75 (False):
# Output: C

Indentation Rules (CRITICAL!):

Python uses indentation to group code, not curly braces {} like other languages:

# Standard: 4 spaces per indentation level
if condition:
    statement1     # 4 spaces
    statement2     # 4 spaces
next_statement     # 0 spaces (not part of if)

Common indentation mistakes:

# WRONG - mixing tabs and spaces (big no-no!)
if x > 10:
    print("A")    # Tab
    print("B")    # 4 spaces  ← Can cause hard-to-see errors!

# WRONG - inconsistent spacing
if x > 10:
  print("A")      # 2 spaces
    print("B")    # 4 spaces  ← IndentationError!

# CORRECT - consistent 4 spaces
if x > 10:
    print("A")    # 4 spaces
    print("B")    # 4 spaces

Best practice: Configure your editor to insert 4 spaces when you press Tab.

Multiple if Statements:

You can have multiple separate if statements - each is independent:

score = 85

if score >= 90:
    print("A grade")  # Not executed (85 < 90)

if score >= 80:
    print("B grade")  # Executed! (85 >= 80)

if score >= 70:
    print("C grade")  # Also executed! (85 >= 70)

# Output:
# B grade
# C grade

Important: These are separate checks! Both the 80 and 70 checks run because they're independent if statements. Later you'll learn elif to make them mutually exclusive.

Common Mistakes and Solutions:

  1. Missing colon:
    # WRONG:
if age >= 18
    print("Adult")
# SyntaxError: invalid syntax

# CORRECT:
if age >= 18:
    print("Adult")
  2. Using = instead of ==:
    # WRONG:
if age = 18:  # This tries to ASSIGN, not compare!
    print("Adult")
# SyntaxError: invalid syntax

# CORRECT:
if age == 18:  # Comparison
    print("Adult")
  3. Forgetting indentation:
    # WRONG:
if score > 90:
print("Great!")  # IndentationError!

# CORRECT:
if score > 90:
    print("Great!")
  4. Indenting code that shouldn't be:
    if temperature > 100:
    print("Boiling")   # Runs only if True
    print("Done")      # Also only if True!

# Probably wanted:
if temperature > 100:
    print("Boiling")   # Runs only if True
print("Done")          # Always runs

exercise.instructions:
Build a Password Strength Checker that validates a password against multiple security criteria.

Password Requirements:

  • Length must be at least 8 characters
  • Must contain at least one number
  • Must not be a common password (check against "password", "12345678", "qwerty")

Your task:

  1. Ask the user to enter a password
  2. Check each requirement using separate if statements
  3. Give specific feedback for each check
  4. Count how many requirements were met

Example output:

=== Password Strength Checker ===

Enter your password: MyP@ss2024

Checking password strength...
✓ Password length is sufficient (10 characters)
✓ Password contains at least one number
✓ Password is not commonly used

Password strength: 3/3 requirements met
Your password is strong!

Hints:

  • Use len(password) to check length
  • Use password.isalnum() or check if any(char.isdigit() for char in password)
  • Use != or not in to check against common passwords
exercise.starter_code:
# Password Strength Checker
# Validate password against security criteria

print("=== Password Strength Checker ===")
print()

password = input("Enter your password: ")

print("\nChecking password strength...")

# Counter for requirements met
requirements_met = 0

# YOUR CODE HERE:
# Check 1: Length requirement (>= 8 characters)
if :
    print(f"✓ Password length is sufficient ({len(password)} characters)")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# Check 2: Contains at least one number
# Hint: Use any(char.isdigit() for char in password)
has_number = any(char.isdigit() for char in password)
if :
    print("✓ Password contains at least one number")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# Check 3: Not a common password
common_passwords = ["password", "12345678", "qwerty"]
if :
    print("✓ Password is not commonly used")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# Display final result
print(f"\nPassword strength: {requirements_met}/3 requirements met")

if requirements_met == 3:
    print("Your password is strong!")

if requirements_met < 3:
    print("Your password needs improvement.")
exercise.hint: For Check 1, use len(password) >= 8. For Check 2, the variable has_number is already set up - just check if has_number is True (or just write 'if has_number:'). For Check 3, use 'password not in common_passwords' or check each one separately.

solution.code:
# Password Strength Checker - SOLUTION
# Validate password against security criteria

print("=== Password Strength Checker ===")
print()

password = input("Enter your password: ")

print("\nChecking password strength...")

# Counter for requirements met
requirements_met = 0

# Check 1: Length requirement (>= 8 characters)
if len(password) >= 8:
    print(f"✓ Password length is sufficient ({len(password)} characters)")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# Check 2: Contains at least one number
has_number = any(char.isdigit() for char in password)
if has_number:
    print("✓ Password contains at least one number")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# Check 3: Not a common password
common_passwords = ["password", "12345678", "qwerty"]
if password not in common_passwords:
    print("✓ Password is not commonly used")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# Display final result
print(f"\nPassword strength: {requirements_met}/3 requirements met")

if requirements_met == 3:
    print("Your password is strong!")

if requirements_met < 3:
    print("Your password needs improvement.")
solution.explanation:
How the Solution Works:

1. Length Check

if len(password) >= 8:
    print(f"✓ Password length is sufficient ({len(password)} characters)")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

What happens:

  • len(password) counts the characters in the string
  • If >= 8, prints success message and increments counter
  • If < 8, the entire if block is skipped

2. Number Check

has_number = any(char.isdigit() for char in password)
if has_number:
    print("✓ Password contains at least one number")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

How it works:

  • char.isdigit() checks if a character is a number (0-9)
  • for char in password loops through each character (preview of loops!)
  • any(...) returns True if ANY character is a digit
  • If has_number is True, the if block runs

Example:

  • "MyPass2024" → has_number = True (contains 2, 0, 2, 4)
  • "MyPassword" → has_number = False (no digits)

3. Common Password Check

common_passwords = ["password", "12345678", "qwerty"]
if password not in common_passwords:
    print("✓ Password is not commonly used")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

What happens:

  • not in checks if password is NOT in the list
  • If the password is NOT common, the if block runs
  • If the password IS common (in the list), the block is skipped

4. Counter Pattern

requirements_met = 0  # Start at zero

if condition1:
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1  # Add 1 if True

if condition2:
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1  # Add 1 if True

# Final count = number of True conditions

This pattern lets us count how many checks passed!

5. Final Feedback

if requirements_met == 3:
    print("Your password is strong!")

if requirements_met < 3:
    print("Your password needs improvement.")

Note: These are separate if statements, so both could technically run if we didn't structure them correctly. Later you'll learn elif to make these mutually exclusive!

Testing Different Passwords:

PasswordLength OK?Has Number?Not Common?Score
"abc"❌ (3 chars)❌✓1/3
"password"✓ (8 chars)❌❌ (common)1/3
"MyPass2024"✓ (10 chars)✓ (has 2,0,2,4)✓3/3
"12345678"✓ (8 chars)✓ (all numbers)❌ (common)2/3

Common Mistakes:

  1. Forgetting to increment counter:
    # WRONG:
if len(password) >= 8:
    print("✓ Length OK")
    # Forgot to add to requirements_met!

# CORRECT:
if len(password) >= 8:
    print("✓ Length OK")
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1
  2. Using 'in' instead of 'not in':
    # WRONG: This gives a point for USING a common password!
if password in common_passwords:
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1

# CORRECT: Give a point for NOT using a common password
if password not in common_passwords:
    requirements_met = requirements_met + 1
  3. Incorrect indentation:
    # WRONG:
if len(password) >= 8:
print("✓ Length OK")  # IndentationError!

# CORRECT:
if len(password) >= 8:
    print("✓ Length OK")  # Indented!

Enhancement Ideas:

Once you master if statements, you could add:

  • Check for uppercase letters
  • Check for special characters (@, #, $, etc.)
  • Give feedback for each failed check ("❌ Password too short")
  • Calculate a strength percentage

key_takeaways:
• if statements make code conditional - it only runs when the condition is True
  • Syntax: if condition: (keyword, condition, colon, indentation)
  • Indentation is MANDATORY in Python - use 4 spaces consistently
  • The colon (:) after the condition is required - don't forget it!
  • Code flow: Python evaluates the condition, runs indented code if True, skips it if False
  • Multiple if statements are independent - each check runs separately
  • Common mistakes:
    • Missing colon
    • Wrong indentation (too much, too little, mixing tabs/spaces)
    • Using = instead of ==
    • Indenting code that should always run
  • if works with any Boolean: comparisons, logical operators, Boolean variables

Before Moving On:

Make sure you can:

  • Write a basic if statement with proper syntax
  • Indent code correctly (4 spaces)
  • Explain what happens when condition is True vs False
  • Debug common indentation and syntax errors

Coming Up Next:

In Lesson 4: if-else Statements, you'll learn to handle BOTH paths:

  • "IF condition is True, do this; ELSE do that"
  • Guaranteeing one of two paths always executes
  • Building programs that handle all scenarios

Right now, your if statements only do something when True. With if-else, you'll handle BOTH True AND False cases explicitly!
